TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: uzai a marevaław ka sitsuayan.
ozai a marevaljaw ka sicoayan.
S.TRANSL: Once upon a time there was a couple,

S.FORM: uzai a uqałay a ałak.
ozai a oqaljay a aljak.
S.TRANSL: and they had a son.

S.FORM: sa nasemvał azua kina.
sa nasemvalj azoa kina.
S.TRANSL: The mother was carrying the child on her back.

S.FORM: qau azua kina: "vaiku a kikasiw," ayain a kama.
qao azoa kina: "vaiko a kikasiw," ayain a kama.
S.TRANSL: The mother said to the father: “Go and get some wood.”

S.FORM: qau "ui, vaik aken a kikasiw," aya a kama.
qao "oi, vaik aken a kikasiw," aya a kama.
S.TRANSL: “Right, I’m off to get wood,” said the father.

S.FORM: qau kematsu ta tsalis a laḍuaḍuq, sa vaik a kikasiw.
qao kemaco ta calis a ladroadroq, sa vaik a kikasiw.
S.TRANSL: He took a long rope, and went to get wood.

S.FORM: manu uzai a qanivung a ḍusa qapuluan.
mano ozai a qanivong a drosa qapoloan.
S.TRANSL: There were two phoenix bushes.

S.FORM: ini seqasi; vengetjen tua tsalis, sa vatsaqi.
ini seqasi; vengetjen toa calis, sa vacaqi.
S.TRANSL: He didn’t cut them, but tied them with the rope, and put them on a pole to carry.

S.FORM: łakua ini pakakatsu.
ljakoa ini pakakaco.
S.TRANSL: But he couldn’t carry them.

S.FORM: qau ini katsu-i a kasiw; vaik a tjumaq.
qao ini kaco-i a kasiw; vaik a tjomaq.
S.TRANSL: So he took no wood, and went off home.

S.FORM: qau sa tjumał tua vaław: "liaw aravats a ku kinikasiw.
qao sa tjomalj toa valjaw: "liaw aravac a ko kinikasiw.
S.TRANSL: And he told his wife: “I’ve collected lots of wood.

S.FORM: ini pakakatsu aken.
ini pakakaco aken.
S.TRANSL: I couldn’t carry it.

S.FORM: vaiku a malap," ayain a vaław a vavayan.
vaiko a malap," ayain a valjaw a vavayan.
S.TRANSL: Go and get it,” he said to his wife.

S.FORM: qau pazazekazekatjen nua vavayan: "aitsu a keḍikeḍi lała-u anga tua załum, sa papavanavi anga; sa supu-i anga a djurikuku," ayain a vaław a uqałay.
qao pazazekazekatjen noa vavayan: "aico a kedrikedri lalja-o anga toa zaljom, sa papavanavi anga; sa sopo-i anga a djorikoko," ayain a valjaw a oqaljay.
S.TRANSL: The woman gave him an order: “Heat up some water for this child and bathe him; and count the chickens,” said the wife to the man.

S.FORM: qau a vaław a vavayan sa vaik a kikasiw.
qao a valjaw a vavayan sa vaik a kikasiw.
S.TRANSL: And the wife went to get the wood.

S.FORM: qau a uqałay a vaław lałain a załum a papinatuk, sa pataladjen a keḍikeḍi.
qao a oqaljay a valjaw laljain a zaljom a papinatok, sa pataladjen a kedrikedri.
S.TRANSL: So the husband heated some water till it was boiling, and put the child in it.

S.FORM: navungisir anga azua keḍikeḍi a namatsay anga.
navongisir anga azoa kedrikedri a namacay anga.
S.TRANSL: The child died with teeth bared(?).

S.FORM: qau azua vaław a uqałay: "masalusalu a keḍikeḍi a ku papavanavan," ayaya malevaleva tua namatsay anga a keḍikeḍi.
qao azoa valjaw a oqaljay: "masalosalo a kedrikedri a ko papavanavan," ayaya malevaleva toa namacay anga a kedrikedri.
S.TRANSL: The husband thought: “The child is glad I’ve bathed it,” and he was happy about the dead child.

S.FORM: qau pakanan a djurikuku uta, sa djameqi, sa penipeniḍi a liqu; qau sa kelayan pitjua djełep.
qao pakanan a djorikoko ota, sa djameqi, sa penipenidri a liqo; qao sa kelayan pitjoa djeljep.
S.TRANSL: He fed the chickens too; then caught them and wrung their necks, and hung them up on the wall.

S.FORM: qau azua vavayan vaik a malap tua kinikasiw.
qao azoa vavayan vaik a malap toa kinikasiw.
S.TRANSL: The woman went to collect the wood he had gathered.

S.FORM: manu inika kasiw; qapulu nua qanivung.
mano inika kasiw; qapolo noa qanivong.
S.TRANSL: But it wasn’t wood; it was whole phoenix bushes.

S.FORM: qau tsemikel a tjumaq azua vavayan.
qao cemikel a tjomaq azoa vavayan.
S.TRANSL: So she returned home.

S.FORM: "su sinupu anga a djurikuku?" ayain a kivadaq a vaław a uqałay.
"so sinopo anga a djorikoko?" ayain a kivadaq a valjaw a oqaljay.
S.TRANSL: “Have you counted the chickens?” she asked her husband.

S.FORM: "sinupu anga azua ku sinikelay," ayain.
"sinopo anga azoa ko sinikelay," ayain.
S.TRANSL: “I’ve counted the ones I’ve hung up,” he told her.

S.FORM: qenetjan nua vavayan; namatsay anga a djurikuku a penułat.
qenetjan noa vavayan; namacay anga a djorikoko a penoljat.
S.TRANSL: The woman had a look; all the chickens were dead.

S.FORM: limutseng aravats a vavayan.
limoceng aravac a vavayan.
S.TRANSL: The woman was very angry.

S.FORM: qau kivadaqan uta: "pinapavanavan anga a keḍikeḍi?" ayain a kivadaq.
qao kivadaqan ota: "pinapavanavan anga a kedrikedri?" ayain a kivadaq.
S.TRANSL: She also asked: “Has the child had a bath?” she asked him.

S.FORM: "ui, ku pinapavanavan anga; masalu aravats, djemelidjeli a naqemereng," aya tua namatsay anga.
"oi, ko pinapavanavan anga; masalo aravac, djemelidjeli a naqemereng," aya toa namacay anga.
S.TRANSL: “Yes, I’ve bathed him. He liked it very much; he’s lying there smiling,” he said about the dead child.

S.FORM: vaiken a kiqenetj nua vavayan.
vaiken a kiqenetj noa vavayan.
S.TRANSL: The woman went to look at it.

S.FORM: mintu namatsay anga.
minto namacay anga.
S.TRANSL: And it was dead.

S.FORM: puvarung aravats azua vavayan; qemaung anga.
povarong aravac azoa vavayan; qemaong anga.
S.TRANSL: The woman was very upset, and cried.

S.FORM: qau kiłavaran a uqałay: "aku qemaung sun a paqeteleng?
qao kiljavaran a oqaljay: "ako qemaong son a paqeteleng?
S.TRANSL: The man said: “Why are you being so silly as to cry?

S.FORM: a djemelidjeli a keḍikeḍi."
a djemelidjeli a kedrikedri."
S.TRANSL: The child is smiling.”

S.FORM: kiłavaran a vavayan: "aya itjen tua namatsay anga?" aya.
kiljavaran a vavayan: "aya itjen toa namacay anga?" aya.
S.TRANSL: The woman said: “Do we talk like that about the dead?”

S.FORM: qau sa qaung anga azua vavayan.
qao sa qaong anga azoa vavayan.
S.TRANSL: And the woman cried.

S.FORM: qau tsuay anga, "alapu tua titaw katua pungki," ayain a uqałay.
qao coay anga, "alapo toa titaw katoa pongki," ayain a oqaljay.
S.TRANSL: After a time she said to the man: “Take a hoe and basket.

S.FORM: qau vaik a malap tua titaw katua pungki; sa vaik tiamadju a sema tsemtsemel.
qao vaik a malap toa titaw katoa pongki; sa vaik tiamadjo a sema cemcemel.
S.TRANSL: So he went and got a hoe and basket; and they went off into the woods.

S.FORM: qau "kali-u tsu a imaza," ayain.
qao "kali-o co a imaza," ayain.
S.TRANSL: “Dig here,” she told him.

S.FORM: kaliin nua uqałay.
kaliin noa oqaljay.
S.TRANSL: The man dug there.

S.FORM: qau sa muri tsevełen azua keḍikeḍi.
qao sa mori ceveljen azoa kedrikedri.
S.TRANSL: The child was to be buried.

S.FORM: manu magarang a uqałay: "aku tsevełen a paqeteleng, a masalusalu a djemelidjeli a keḍikeḍi?"
mano magarang a oqaljay: "ako ceveljen a paqeteleng, a masalosalo a djemelidjeli a kedrikedri?"
S.TRANSL: But the man was angry: “Why are you being so silly as to bury him? The child is happy and smiling.”

S.FORM: "namatsay anga," ayain nua vavayan.
"namacay anga," ayain noa vavayan.
S.TRANSL: “He’s dead,” the woman told him.

S.FORM: qau tsevełen anga nimadju.
qao ceveljen anga nimadjo.
S.TRANSL: And she buried him.

S.FORM: qau sa tulu-i anga azua uqałay: "nu mapuvaruvarung a tja salasaladj, nu qemauqaung, tja pusaladjan a mapuvarung a qemaung, saka nangaq."
qao sa tolo-i anga azoa oqaljay: "no mapovarovarong a tja salasaladj, no qemaoqaong, tja posaladjan a mapovarong a qemaong, saka nangaq."
S.TRANSL: Then the man was taught: “When our friends are upset and cry, we join them in being upset and crying; that’s the right thing to do.”

S.FORM: qau tsuatsuay anga manu uzai a pakaikaiv.
qao coacoay anga mano ozai a pakaikaiv.
S.TRANSL: After a time some people gave a wedding supper,

S.FORM: qau vaik a kiqepu tiamadju.
qao vaik a kiqepo tiamadjo.
S.TRANSL: and they went to it.

S.FORM: manu qemaung azua pinakaivan a vavayan.
mano qemaong azoa pinakaivan a vavayan.
S.TRANSL: The bride for whom the supper was given cried;

S.FORM: mintu qemaung uta azua uqałay.
minto qemaong ota azoa oqaljay.
S.TRANSL: and then the man cried too.

S.FORM: qau kirivuan nua vaław a vavayan: "aku qemaung sun a paqeteleng?" ayain.
qao kirivoan noa valjaw a vavayan: "ako qemaong son a paqeteleng?" ayain.
S.TRANSL: He was told off by his wife: “Why are you being so silly as to cry?” she said to him.

S.FORM: "'nu qemauqaung a qaliqali, qemaung itjen a pusaladj,' aya sun.
"'no qemaoqaong a qaliqali, qemaong itjen a posaladj,' aya son.
S.TRANSL: “You said: ‘When other people cry, we join them in crying.’

S.FORM: aku kirivu sun a paqeteleng?" ayain a vavayan.
ako kirivo son a paqeteleng?" ayain a vavayan.
S.TRANSL: So why on earth are you scolding me?” he said to her.

S.FORM: qau keman ta tsengeł.
qao keman ta cengelj.
S.TRANSL: Once they were eating lunch.

S.FORM: nu pałetekutekuin, pułapułaten a djemamay nua uqałay.
no paljetekotekoin, poljapoljaten a djemamay noa oqaljay.
S.TRANSL: When the food was being put on the table, the man ate up all the side dishes.

S.FORM: qau masiaq azua vavayan.
qao masiaq azoa vavayan.
S.TRANSL: The woman was ashamed.

S.FORM: "maya djemamay aravats.
"maya djemamay aravac.
S.TRANSL: “Don’t eat so much of the side dishes.

S.FORM: ku qadjayay a su lima.
ko qadjayay a so lima.
S.TRANSL: I’ll tie a string round your arm.

S.FORM: nu ku tsiḍtsiḍen, djamayu," ayain.
no ko cidrcidren, djamayo," ayain.
S.TRANSL: When I tug it, you can eat some,” she said to him.

S.FORM: nu tsuay anga ini tsiḍtsiḍi.
no coay anga ini cidrcidri.
S.TRANSL: For a long time there was no tug.

S.FORM: "aku ini anga su tsiḍtsiḍtsiḍi?" aya a uqałay.
"ako ini anga so cidrcidrcidri?" aya a oqaljay.
S.TRANSL: “Why haven’t you tugged yet?” said the man.

S.FORM: manu tjemala tideq sa paqaqułuts a vatu.
mano tjemala tideq sa paqaqoljoc a vato.
S.TRANSL: Then some dogs came into the space between them and started a tussle;

S.FORM: qau matsiḍtsiḍ a lima.
qao macidrcidr a lima.
S.TRANSL: and so his arm got tugged.

S.FORM: tjadjaław anan a djemamay.
tjadjaljaw anan a djemamay.
S.TRANSL: He went at the side dishes even more crazily (?even quicker).

S.FORM: qau pułaten anga a djamay.
qao poljaten anga a djamay.
S.TRANSL: He ate up all the side dishes;

S.FORM: nekanga nu sidjamay nua qaliqali.
nekanga no sidjamay noa qaliqali.
S.TRANSL: there was nothing left for anyone else.
